course_title: Pain and clinical sciences in musculoskeletal and sports and exercise physiotherapy

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding of evidence-informed practice and advanced clinical reasoning in musculoskeletal and sports and exercise physiotherapy.
Understand different types of pain and underlying mechanisms.
Describe and demonstrate the use of patient-reported and clinical outcome measures of pain, function and disability in the assessment and treatment of sports and musculoskeletal injuries.
Demonstrate an in depth understanding and awareness of person-centred care/practice.
Demonstrate an in depth understanding of when a client should be referred to other health care professionals.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to analyse one of four cases, and provide a case formulation exploring the different biological, psychological and social contributors to the patient's pain presentation. Students must then provide an analysis of this case formulation and planned assessments from this. They will then design a management plan based on their case formulation and projected assessment findings.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will select a spinal condition (from a list of topics), and give a 5-minute presentation that demonstrates their understanding of the relevant research surrounding the evidence-based management of the condition.

Presentations will be delivered live, using the powerpoint slide template provided on Learn.UQ (Ultra). Students will have 5 minutes for their presentation, followed by 5 minutes of questions from the examiner.

When a student is required to complete an oral or practical assessment item worth 20% or more, the performance will be recorded and retained per Appendix 1. (Assessment Procedure (95) )

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be required to provide a written report of a case study based on a challenging patient with an upper or lower limb condition that they have treated this year.

The report will include a body chart of symptoms and key clinical exam findings, as well as an outline and discussion of the patho-mechanical basis for their specific presentation, and clinical reasoning behind the assessment and chosen treatment / management.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission of assessment items will attract a penalty of 10% of the maximum mark per day late or, for work graded on a 1-7 scale, a deduction of one grade per day (including weekends and public holidays), unless a formal extension has been organised prior to the due date.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 9(23 Feb - 26 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
PHTY7951 Webcasts

Each week you will have access to approximately 2 hours of online, pre-recorded, self-paced webcasts, and up to 2 hours of associated reading. The content is organised in three Modules, and covers:

  1. Pain: nociceptive pain, neuropathic pain, nociplastic pain, psychological and social aspects of pain, and medical and physiotherapy management of pain.
  2. Spine, Arthritis and Imaging: assessment, management and clinical cases of the cervical spine, thoracic spine, lumbar spine and sacroiliac joint; arthritis; and imaging in musculoskeletal and sports physiotherapy.
  3. Upper and Lower Limbs: assessment, management and clinical cases of the shoulder girdle, elbow, wrist and hand, hip and pelvis, knee, and ankle and foot.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 8(02 Mar - 19 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Online drop-in sessions

Drop-in sessions give you an opportunity to ask any questions about the course content or your progress on the assessment tasks. These will be held online, during the second week of each module:

  1. Week 2 (Thursday March 5th 4-5pm AEST)
  2. Week 5 (Thursday March 26th 4-5pm AEST)
  3. Week 8 (Thursday April 23rd 4-5pm AEST)

Attendance is optional. Drop-in sessions will be recorded and available on Learn.UQ (Ultra) for students who are unable to attend.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
